title: Mike Dean handed FA Cup TV tie as Premier League look to embrace video technology for refs
text:

Under-fire referee Mike Dean has been given another high-profile TV game despite his red card nightmare at West Ham . 
Premier League ref Dean will take charge of Tottenham’s FA Cup third round clash with Aston Villa on Sunday which is being shown live on BBC1. 
That comes even though Dean’s dismissal of West Ham’s Sofiane Feghouli could be overturned on Wednesday while Mirror Sport can reveal the Premier League are also taking steps towards embracing video technology in the future. 
West Ham have appealed Feghouli’s red card for his challenge on Manchester United defender Phil Jones which will be heard by an FA commission. Mike Dean has been given another high-profile TV game despite his red card nightmare at West Ham (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Dean’s decision has led to increased calls for video technology to be used and the Premier League are taking their own steps to be ahead of the game. 
FIFA are carrying out a two-year experiment - which included the World Club Championship in Japan last month - to see if they can use video technology during games. 
The Premier League have been conducting their own trials at IMG studios in London who broadcast games and programmes for foreign TV rights holders and broadcasters. Read More Ex-Premier League referees Graham Poll and Mark Halsey criticise Mike Dean's performance A Video Technology official was tested at the recent FIFA Club World Cup (Photo: Shaun Botterill - FIFA) 
Former referees have been used on a regular basis to be in the studio’s match centre to watch games and then experiment with mocked-up radio links to match officials to see if it would work.
